claim.text: Younger personas, i.e., 2- and 4-year-old personas, obtain a smaller reward than older ones, i.e., 13- and 20-year-old personas.
claim.exact_quote: With an increasing number of trials, the LLM obtains a higher average reward, corroborating that Vicuna-13B is able to learn from past trials to improve its policy similarly to GPT-3 in [8]. Moreover, as the LLM takes on a persona of different ages, we observe a divergence of obtained rewards as the number of trials increases. Younger personas, i.e., 2- and 4-year-old personas, obtain a smaller reward than older ones, i.e., 13- and 20-year-old personas.

evidence.evidence_text: Figure 2 (top) shows the average reward per trial the LLM obtained with personas of increasing age.
evidence.limitations: The study only considered a small number of age groups (2, 4, 7, 13, and 20).
evidence.exact_quote: First, we show the average reward per trial the LLM obtained with personas of increasing age in Figure 2 (top).

evaluation.justification: The evidence provides a clear visual representation of the difference in average reward obtained by younger and older personas.
evaluation.key_limitations: The study did not explore the impact of other factors, such as gender or socioeconomic status, on task performance.

claim.text: LLMs impersonating older participants generate higher average rewards until age 20.
claim.exact_quote: We find that the impersonating LLMs generally improved over trials, i.e. they increase their rewards as they progressed over trials of a game (β = 0.63, p < .001 for ages 2–20 and β = 0.60, p < .001 for ages 20–60). Importantly, LLMs impersonating older participants generate higher average rewards until age 20 (β = 0.17, p < .001), thereby replicating a general pattern found in the developmental literature [70].

evidence.evidence_text: The results of a regression analysis show that age had a positive effect on the expected reward, with LLMs impersonating older participants generating higher average rewards until age 20.
evidence.limitations: The study only considered a small number of age groups (2, 4, 7, 13, and 20).
evidence.exact_quote: Secondly, we analyze the resulting rewards by using a regression, entering the trial number and age as independent variables. (...) We find that the impersonating LLMs generally improved over trials, i.e. they increase their rewards as they progressed over trials of a game (β = 0.63, p < .001 for ages 2–20 and β = 0.60, p < .001 for ages 20–60). Importantly, LLMs impersonating older participants generate higher average rewards until age 20 (β = 0.17, p < .001), thereby replicating a general pattern found in the developmental literature [70].

evaluation.justification: The evidence provides statistical support for the claim that LLMs impersonating older participants generate higher average rewards until age 20.
evaluation.key_limitations: The study did not explore the impact of other factors, such as gender or socioeconomic status, on task performance.
